facts.text: Decree passed on August 26, 1931 in Summary Suit No. 3437 of 1930 by the High Court of Bombay against three defendants who were residents of Parbhani district in the former State of Hyderabad.
Before the decree was passed, the appellant applied for leave to defend and leave was conditionally granted on his depositing Rs. 5,000 within four weeks.
Appellant failed to deposit Rs. 5,000 within four weeks.
On appellant's failure to deposit, an ex-parte decree was granted for Rs. 52,032-7-0 including costs and future interest at 6% per annum.
Appellant did not file any written statement.
Decree was transferred for execution to the District Judge, Bhir, in Hyderabad State.
Respondent took out execution on June 18, 1954 in the Court of the District Judge, Bhir.

Appellant objected to execution, inter alia, on the ground that he had not submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court which was a foreign court and therefore the decree was a foreign decree and could not be executed in the Court at Bhir.
Appeal taken to the High Court, held on July 29, 1958 that the appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court; appeal dismissed and order of Executing Court upheld.
Letters Patent appeal against High Court judgment dismissed in limine on October 24, 1958.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate of the High Court under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court, rendering the decree executable in the Court at Bhir.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant had not submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court which was a foreign court and therefore the decree was a foreign decree and could not be executed in the Court at Bhir.

court_reasoning.text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is not compellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction by applying for leave to defend without objecting to jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Appellant submitted to the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court by appearing and applying for leave to defend without objection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shaikh Atham Sahib v. Davud Sahib
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle that appearance and application for leave to defend without jurisdictional objection constitutes voluntary submission to foreign court's jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate granting appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Bombay High Court order upholding execution of decree dismissed, confirming appellant's submission to Bombay High Court's jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: A person who appears in obedience to the process of a foreign Court and applies for leave to defend the suit without objecting to the jurisdiction of the Court when he is not compellable by law to do so must be held to have voluntarily submitted to jurisdiction of such Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal principle applied to hold appellant submitted to jurisdiction.
